utterances.speaker: TUCKER CARLSON, HOST
utterances.utterance: Good evening and welcome to "Tucker Carlson Tonight." For days, we have watched as a growing Caravan on - of Honduran nationals has snaked northward toward our border to claim asylum here. The spectacle has been televised from the very start and it has spoke - sparked an explosive political debate. Now, more migrants are on the way. There are reports tonight that another Caravan of asylum seekers, this one organized exclusively on social media, is planning to leave from El Salvador next week heading here. You can be certain then when and if that group actually arrives here, the usual red-faced cable news anchors will demand that we let them in immediately, no questions asked. Never mind that one-third of all Salvadorans on Earth already live here in the United States. It is our duty, they will tell us. Once those anchors get off the air they will return home to entirely immigrant-free neighborhoods feeling good about themselves. The only Salvadorans they will ever meet personally are those doing their laundry for minimum wage. But ignore the hypocrisy, if you can. Stifle your personal concerns about mass immigration. People are suffering, they're telling us. And only America can save them. If you've been watching television you've seen pictures like this all day of desperate poverty and hopelessness.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Now reached California.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh sorry about that. That was the wrong tape. That was not a slum outside Tegucigalpa. That video was shot right here in Orange County, California, not far from Disneyland. The desperate and impoverished people on the screen you saw were American citizens. Hundreds of thousands of them sleep on the ground every night in this country. They don't make it on CNN very often. They're just Americans. Their tragedy is not interesting. If they did laundry at five bucks an hour for rich people though, our moral superiors might notice and care. But as of now, no. The cable news geniuses could not be less concerned about what is happening to American citizens, which, if you think about it, kind of explains the Trump phenomenon. One of the great mysteries here in Washington is how a president with no prior political experience, who's emotionally volatile and not very articulate, remains nevertheless so very popular outside of Washington. It doesn't make any sense. But of course, it makes sense. Trump's secret, he says things like this.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: They have a word. It sort of became old-fashioned. It's called a nationalist. And I say "Really? We're not supposed to use that word." You know what I am? I'm a nationalist, OK? I'm a nationalist.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: A nationalist, in other words, a leader who puts his own country first, who cares about his own people most. You'd think everyone in charge of a nation would be a nationalist. Putting interests of your own citizens above those of citizens of other countries was once considered a prerequisite for running a democracy, not anymore. Now it's considered immoral, evil, in fact. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN
utterances.utterance: Nationalist. Use that word. We're going to talk about that word tonight. It is a favorite of the Alt-Right and is loaded with nativists and racial undertones.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS CILLIZZA, CNN
utterances.utterance: He's weaponized race and sort of nationalism and dog whistles.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN
utterances.utterance: You're suggesting there's some kind of dog whistle there.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BEN CARDIN, D-MD.
utterances.utterance: It is. It is. It applies - it - it - it does provoke hate activities.

utterances.speaker: BILL BURTON, POLITICAL CONSULTANT
utterances.utterance: What are you trying to say as President of the United States that you're a nationalist? Americans know what that means. It's not even a dog whistle anymore. It's a bull horn.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Not a whistle. It's a bull horn. Hitler was a nationalist. Of course, so were Mahatma Gandhi and Abraham Lincoln, and every other leader of every other nation state throughout history until about 20 minutes ago, but whatever. Nationalism provokes "Hate activity," says a sitting U.S. Senator. All the cable news geniuses say, "Amen."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: There was a time in my lifetime, I'm not that old, when a - when a picture like that would have just elicited nothing but sympathy and empathy--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: --among the American people.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You see that you think, Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: What must be happening where those people are coming from?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: How can we open our arms to people like that?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: These people are coming and asking for asylum. Guess what Ben? It's in our laws that people are allowed to come to our borders and ask for asylum.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN EDWARD SCHMIDT, AMERICAN COMMUNICATIONS AND PUBLIC AFFAIRS STRATEGIST
utterances.utterance: This is a moral outrage that harkens to the worst accesses in the history of the country, to the separation of families at the slave auction blocks--

utterances.speaker: ROSIE O'DONNELL, ACTRESS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHMIDT
utterances.utterance: --to the separation of Native American families.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Hope you're following that at home. Immigration, it turns out, is not a civic question that American voters might be allowed to have opinions about. It's bigger than that. It's a moral outrage. It's a humanitarian crisis. The law is irrelevant here, so are any of your stupid selfish concerns about the effect of impoverished foreigners moving into your neighborhood or your school district. The rule here is simple. Listen carefully. If people from a place poorer than America want to move to America, they get to do that. Period. If you disagree or complain or do anything other than recite the poem at the bottom of the Statue of Liberty, you are, well you already know what you are, because you've heard it a thousand times, but we're going to tell you again anyway, maybe this time it will penetrate, you are a racist.

utterances.speaker: JOY REID, NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: They see those pictures and are being told fear those Brown people.

utterances.speaker: KARINE JEAN-PIERRE, HAITIAN-AMERICAN POLITICAL CAMPAIGN ORGANIZER, ACTIVIST, POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, LECTURER, SENIOR ADVISOR AND NATIONAL SPOKESWOMAN FOR MOVEON.ORG
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: JOHN HARWOOD, CNBC'S CHIEF WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT, THE NEW YORK TIMES CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: The Democrats are a diverse party. The Republicans appeal disproportionately to older Whites. And the mob thing is an attempt to alarm those voters about the prospect of non-Whites and immigrants.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN PATRICK STELTER, CNN'S SENIOR MEDIA CORRESPONDENT, RELIABLE SOURCES HOST
utterances.utterance: The Right-wing coverage of this is it - is it demagoguery? How would you describe this?

utterances.speaker: MAX BOOT, AMERICAN AUTHOR, CONSULTANT, EDITORIALIST, LECTURER, MILITARY HISTORIAN
utterances.utterance: It is demagoguery, Brian. It is also, I believe, racism and nativism, really pandering to the fears of Trump supporters and Fox News viewers.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. You're racist just like you were racist for opposing Obamacare or not watching Sunday Night Football or believing that Brett Kavanaugh did not sexually assault someone. You are a bigot until the moment you obey the Democratic Party, at which point you are a good person like Al Sharpton or Louis Farrakhan. You know the drill. There's one interesting new twist in this latest propaganda barrage though, fear. If you're against admitting an entire Caravan full of poor people into this country it's because you've been coached by that dastardly Fox News to fear the people in the Caravan. But let's be honest. That's not really true. There are a lot of reasons to oppose admitting this Caravan full of people. We don't need any more low- wage labor in this country, for one thing. We also have a right to decide who occupies our property, that's always true. Show up uninvited at Joy Reid's house and you'll discover that she agrees with that principle too. So there are good reasons to oppose this. Fear of Hondurans isn't really one of them. By and large, these are not scary people. Mostly, they're just poor people from crappy countries who want a better life. That's understandable. Nobody blames them for that. Nobody's really afraid of these people. What normal people are afraid of is this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: TED CRUZ, JUNIOR UNITED STATES SENATOR, TEXAS
utterances.utterance: God bless you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: And this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Get off. Get off. Stop fighting.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, look closely at those videos. What didn't you see in them? Migrant fruit pickers from Honduras. There weren't any. There wasn't a single impoverished Central American immigrant. The only work boots you saw in those videos were from Brooklyn. They're part of the historic - hipster costume. They're not real. Those were thoroughly American kids, kids with clean fingernails, children of privilege. Those are people with four-year college degrees. Some of those people teach in colleges. What you just saw was the Activist-Left. That's a group about as diverse as the checkout line at Whole Foods. These are not immigrants. They're far too pampered and decadent to be immigrants. These are homegrown religious extremists who believe in nothing but their own power. Suddenly, people exactly like this hold Congressional seats, and they host their own TV shows, and they teach at your kids' school. These are the people worth worrying about. So cool it with the lectures about fear. Listen carefully cable news geniuses, it's not impoverished peasants from Central America we're afraid of. It's you. Univision Anchor, Jorge Ramos, joins us tonight from Southern Mexico at the site of the Caravan encampment. Jorge, I am really glad you're here because I've - I've wanted to ask you this question all day. So, in the many times we've spoken, you've explained that immigrants to the United States from Central America are a net addition to our economy. They're America's strength. They make this a much better country. Given that, why isn't Mexico jumping at the chance to absorb these migrants into its economy? Why is it wasting this human capital?

utterances.speaker: JORGE RAMOS, CHIEF NEWS ANCHOR, UNIVISION
utterances.utterance: Well there are - the reality, Tucker, is that most of the immigrants that you see behind me, and as a matter of fact they're not criminals or terrorists or not even immigrants. They're refugees. They don't want to stay here in Mexico. They want to go to the United States. Their plan is just to have a better life in the United States. And - and they are refugees. So, I think we have to treat them with respect. We have to listen to the stories, hear their cases, check their backgrounds. And if they apply for political asylum, go through the process. The reality, Tucker, I understand what you're asking. But the reality is that they don't want to stay in Mexico where, by the way, in the last 12 years, more than 200,000 people were killed. They don't want to stay here. They're fleeing violence and extreme poverty in Honduras, most of them--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --they want to go to the United States. They don't want to stay here in Mexico.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: We need --

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: And in Mexico, by the way, they crossed the border between Guatemala and Mexico. I was there this morning. But that's probably just for the - for Donald Trump to see, just by the bridge, you will see little boats crossing thousands of immigrants in the last few days for--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Wait but - but - but I'm confused--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --Donald Trump to see --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but - but hold on--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --so long it's not for show --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wait but hold on you, OK--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --the reality is completely different.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. So, you say that the United States must show respect to these, what you call, refugees. Why doesn't Mexico show them respect? Mexico is a rich country, the richest in the region. There are more billionaires in Monterrey and Mexico City than there are in Washington D.C. Why are they sleeping on the ground? And why haven't they been taken care of by rich Mexicans of goodwill, the blue-eyed ruling class of which you were a part, why - where are they in this?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, it's a - it's a great question. And I'm so glad that you asked it because Mexicans, despite what you might hear in social media, Mexicans have been treating, all these refugees with incredible generosity, and with incredible solidarity. I know that there are fake stories in - in the United States saying that these people were funded by George Soros and by Democrats or by Nicolas Maduro from Venezuela, Vice President Pence is completely wrong about that because if they really finance these people, it was a scam. I've been talking to people here in - in Chiapas who don't have a single dollar, Tucker, to buy a bottle of water. So there - there's no financing here. And Mexicans--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, no but that's - wait but hold on--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --civilians--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --that's my point.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --not the politicians.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: The politicians, they'll be playing the game with - with Donald Trump. But civilians - Mexicans civilians have been giving all these refugees a little money, water, food, clothes, and sometimes--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But why not - but - but hold on, what about your - I understand and I--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --transportation to go to - to the next town. Yesterday I saw--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --something incredible--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: All right wait, but let me - let me just interrupt you and say I - I--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --and let me tell you, they--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --yesterday they went 26 miles, a marathon, many kids, hundreds of kids, Tucker, and that's the people of the Caravan, no terrorists or criminals.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I - I think most Mexicans are very nice people. I grew up next to Mexico. I always like them. It's your ruling class I'm asking you about, the people who are some of the richest people in the world, who spend the summer in France every year. And again, you're from this group, so you can speak to this. Where are they in this? Why aren't they taking care of these people who are sleeping on the ground? We can see them right behind you.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: I - I was never part of that group.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But where are those people - where are the Mexican billionaires? They're very good at lecturing us about our moral inferiority, but they don't seem to be helping at all. Why?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: No. I think you - you want to concentrate on what Mexicans are doing. I just told you that civilians have done it in a - in a beautiful, generous way. And I think we have to concentrate now on what the role of the United States should be in - in all these crises. First of all, I spent two days with these refugees. And I have not seen a single person from the Middle East. That's a lie. And I think, Tucker, you have - you have to tell the truth to your audience, and you don't have - you have to make sure that people are not lying about this Caravan because- -

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: What--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --the people from the Middle East are not part of this Caravan--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. But wait - what are you - let me just - let me just ask, what are you doing?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --and they're not terrorists. And they simply want a chance to remake --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Wait hold on. What are you - I understand and --

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --their lives.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --look, I'm not there. So I'm not - I can't describe the people there. You said the United States, its taxpayers, me, you know, the other 330 million American citizens--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: Right, of course --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --right - have an obligation. How many of these migrants are you taking in personally into your home and are supporting once they get to the United States?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: I - I think that's a great question. And - and that's precisely the kind of question that people like you ask when you don't want to understand that this has nothing to do with individuals. It has to do with nations. And what we have to understand--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But what's the answer?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --is that these refugees--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --are not a threat to the United States. I know that in - in Fox News they'll be reporting that they--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, but how many are you taking in? It's a very - before you attack the Fox--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --are a threat to the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --it's a simple question--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --sanctuary of the Unites States--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --how many are you - how many are you--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --that is not true. They are - they are not a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --taking in?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --threat to the United States. I think it's really a love letter to the United States. And you know what they're saying at the - in the United States, please help us. You are the only ones who can help us.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I think that's right.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: And that's exactly what--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I agree with you.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --they are asking from President Trump--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I agree with you. I agree.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --and from people like you--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But - but--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --and from all your audience. So, I think it is very important that you send--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but - but - but what about you, hold on--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --that you send correspondents Fox correspondents --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wait, I understand. I'm not attacking--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --to this place and talk to them. And don't--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --don't lie to your audience, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But I'm not lying to the audience.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: Don't tell them that they're terrorists--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to get, hold on - I'm going to - I'm going to stop with this--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --and - and tell them the truth about this Caravan because what you and--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I'm going to stop with this, hold on--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --Fox News and President Trump--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --wait listen, I'm asking you a very simple question.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --are saying about this group is a complete lie.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. Let me just ask you a - and let's - let's - let's answer this question. We can end on this. How many of these migrants are you personally taking responsibility for?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: How many are going home to Jorge's place in Miami at the end of the day? And be - please be specific.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, I think that, again, this has nothing to do with individuals.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh, you don't have to do a thing.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: It has nothing to do with me. I wish I could help all of them but right now - right now--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: How about three?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --we're talking about 7,000 here. We're talking about 2,500 kids. It is impossible for an individual to deal with a crisis like this. I think President Trump's immigration policy has been a complete failure--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Have you donated money personally?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --and unfortunately, Tucker, I - I hope that that you could--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Wait hold on, let me just you --

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --help them too and I wish I could--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --have you donated money?

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --help them too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well, you can.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: I wish we could that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well sure you can.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: I - I wish - I wish we could do something like that but I - but I--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well I think you can.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --bet if your kids were in danger of being raped or being raised in extreme poverty or being threatened with join in--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --Armada or a gang, what will you do? I mean--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I can count on you to do a standup next to them but probably not to help them--

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --will you take the risk? I'm merely telling for the same reason that they're doing--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I noticed.

utterances.speaker: RAMOS
utterances.utterance: --for their kids.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. Jorge, thank you so much. Appreciate it. People are very upset about the migrant crisis, not upset enough to help personally but upset enough to demand that you help. Brit Hume joins us just after the break. Is the mid-term a Blue Wave in the making or is it not? He's been thinking about it. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Mid-term election exactly two weeks from right now. Everything that happens is, in effect, political at the moment. What's going to happen in two weeks? Brit Hume has been thinking about it, and joins us tonight. He's, of course, chief political analyst at Fox.

utterances.speaker: BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.utterance: Senior.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Senior, whatever, the biggest guy at Fox, for sure.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: Or -- or senior moment political analyst.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's - so, the Caravan. I - I hate to make it a political question because I - I think it's a civic question. But it is political. What's the political effect of it?

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: Well, if you think about it from Trump's point of view, here's an issue, immigration, that hadn't been all that prominent this fall, but one that he emphasized, I think, and am sure, he believes to great effect in 2016. So, here comes this Caravan. Now, mind you, Tucker, in terms of, you know, this country and what kind of threat these people pose, these people are - are probably - most of them will probably never get here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: I mean they've got to walk ahead of them. They're all - they already have sore feet, all of them, or most of them. You can see the - the pictures are - are heartbreaking. These people, you know, they're - they're - they're in pain. And so, they - they're marching up through Mexico. They got at least a month to come before they could reach any part of our border. And it all - how long it will take depend on where they go. Most of them probably won't make it, so it's probably not that big a threat in terms of - of a lot of people crossing the border. But it's very visual, as the pictures on the screen right now illustrate. And Americans are looking at this and they see the picture of that bridge, which is just chock-a-block with people, they think what's going on here. So, Trump's out raising hell about it. This helps him, unquestionably, in my view. It's a good issue for him and a good issue by and large for Republicans.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I wonder if Democrats understand that because their cheerleaders, their handmaidens all day long have been acting as if this, you know, is something that everyone would agree with that America has a moral obligation to accept anybody from a poorer country.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: That's a problem that Democrats often have is that they think everybody agrees with them, and they take their cues from elites in New York and Washington and, perhaps, some other places, and they get on board with this stuff. And, you know, there are pockets of the country where that's strong and in other cities and so on. But, you know, one of the things that's happening in this election is that if you look at the - the - the - the classic, what they call the generic ballot, would you rather have a Republican or a Democrat--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: --you need to go. Which party you think should control Congress that number's been very good for Democrats most of this fall. And it's still good on a national basis. But in the - in the places and the crucial races, that number is close to where it's barely a margin for the Democrats at all. And those are the places around the country that they'll need to win to get control of the House. The - I'd still favor that. But they don't favor that as much as they once did, not very many weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, we - sum up the political apocalypse that occurs if Democrats don't take the House back.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: Oh, my lord. Oh, my lord.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Ha-ha, ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: I mean, you know, that you - you would have thought that there would have been a really major reassessment than the appointment of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: --new leaders and so on after what happened in 2016 that the - the - the unlosable race was lost to Donald Trump; it really hasn't happened. Is there a generation of new leaders emerging? Maybe, but they're pretty hard to see now because what you see is Pelosi and - and Chuck Schumer--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: --and - and - and - and Perez and that group and - and the rest of these people are and - and Joe Biden's out on the campaign trail, Obama's out on the campaign trail. This doesn't look like the, you know, the group of tomorrow's leaders.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It really doesn't but if they lose they're going to get a new set, I would say.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: Well their hopes of the Senate look diminished too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: That looks like that's not - probably not going to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Briefly.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: --happen.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Brit Hume, thank you very much for that.

utterances.speaker: HUME
utterances.utterance: You bet, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Senior political analyst. A former aide to Hillary Clinton, high-ranking, is defending the Left's new tactic of screaming at people they disagree with in restaurants. He joins us next, fresh from a restaurant.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Ted Cruz has cast votes that some Democrats don't like. Rather than wait until the election two weeks from now to vote against him, some decided to scream at him and his wife in a restaurant.

utterances.speaker: CRUZ
utterances.utterance: God bless you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Solve this --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You think that putting a sexual assaulter on the court is a victory for women?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Leave him alone.

utterances.speaker: CRUZ
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Sir. God bless you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: So, you believe in man assaulting women. That's what your vote cost today, Senator?

utterances.speaker: CRUZ
utterances.utterance: I believe in due process.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: So, why do you support a man that abuses women?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Leave him alone.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Why doesn't he support women?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Shame on you, Ted Cruz.

utterances.speaker: CRUZ
utterances.utterance: God bless you, Ma'am.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Shame on you, Ted Cruz.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Shame on you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Shame on you, Ted Cruz.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Shame on you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Shame on you, Ted Cruz.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Shame on you, Ted Cruz. Changing minds and annoying travelers at the same time. That wasn't a restaurant, of course. That was Washington National Airport. Cruz is not the only lawmaker getting yelled at these days. Mitch McConnell recently screamed at in a restaurant also. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We have to know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Leave him alone. Leave him alone.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Ditch Mitch.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You want to live in this country? Of course, you don't. Most people are horrified by it. Some people though defend it. Former Hillary Clinton aide, Philippe Reines recently said that the public harassment of lawmakers was a made-up problem. He joins us tonight. Philippe, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: PHILIPPE REINES, FORMER HILLARY CLINTON ADVISER
utterances.utterance: Yes, thank you for having me back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You didn't mean to defend that, I assume.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I wasn't defending Ted Cruz. I - that - those could've been Republicans chanting against Ted Cruz, the way he's so unpopular.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Screaming at - look, screaming at people in public places is not, you know, you could argue it's protected by the First Amendment. That's fine. But it's not the way that people should behave. It's not anything we should defend, and it's not the country we want to live in, is it?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Well let's be clear - clear what happened. First, the first instance of this was Sarah Sanders who--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --was in a restaurant in Virginia.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: At Lexington Virginia and was ejected.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: She was asked very nicely to leave. She was asked nicely more than sometimes you're nice to me in terms of questions. So, I don't think that that is a heavy price to pay for someone who lies with impunity every day to the American people.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. So - so you worked for Hillary Clinton whose--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I did.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --husband was credibly accused of rape. If your mom--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: He was not credibly accused --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --he was accused of rape by someone with all kinds of contemporaneous conversation --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --dismissed by Ken Starr. But that's not what we're here.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying, look, I'm not accusing --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --him of rape. I'm just saying that he was accused of rape. So, you could see someone saying "Well, Philippe defended this. His mother gave birth to him. Why should she be allowed to eat in a restaurant?" It's within bound to say, "Philippe's mom, please leave." How would you feel about that?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Nobody was protesting Sarah Sanders' mother. It was Sarah Sanders.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Because she works for a guy they don't like. Look, I mean I'm just saying maybe --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I mean first of all, she has free will. She doesn't have to work there. It's an honor and a privilege to work there.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well you don't have to defend the Clintons --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: She chooses every day to - she--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but how would you like it if--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --she chooses every day to lie to the American people. People are seeing public officials and they don't see any accountability. And they're thinking to themselves.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: What about elections?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Elections are two weeks. I mean what - what point is this OK? I mean--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I don't know you --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --100 - 100 days ago, I mean--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You - no, no, but you just agree -

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --I'm - I'm not the - I'm not the angry mob.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --the questions --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: A 100 days ago, I started a protest outside the White House.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: You have loyal viewers like Kate Roonie who know that I couldn't hurt a fly. Donald Trump is trying to shut that down because he doesn't want protestors outside.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. I guess the point I'm making is should - is this - is it OK or do things start to fall apart, when you --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you it's not OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --snatching this kind of nonsense --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you it's not OK. It's been--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Lots of things aren't OK.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --it's been--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Is this OK?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --642 days since Donald Trump was sworn in. Not one of those days has he said, "We've got to dial down the rhetoric." I'll tell you what he did say.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: In the last few days - in the last few days, he has specifically--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Have you seen a lot of Democrats been--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --I'll tell you what I saw.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --pushed out of restaurants.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: He specifically - we're not in power. We're not - there's nothing to hold us accountable to.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No. No, because your youth wing--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: In the last week--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --all the little - all the little robots who follow you--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --he specifically--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --are doing this. I mean I know - I must know 10 people who've been yelled at until they had to leave restaurants, all conservatives. Is that OK with you?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: There's nothing --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Is that an OK thing?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --I am OK with Sarah Sanders, Secretary Nielsen, and Mitch McConnell. Yes, Mitch McConnell was more in danger of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You're OK, so--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --salmonella in that restaurant than he was--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, if Hillary Clinton is--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --no one's been arrested.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --in a restaurant and I walk up to her--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I've been with her when she's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --and I start screaming at her--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --accosted.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No but, I - I get it. But are you--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: It's not - there's a difference to that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK with that?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: There's differences between unpleasant--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: If I scream at Hillary until she leaves--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: There's serious difference being unpleasant and something being OK. I will say if you're protesting something, you're disagreeing with that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: But how about you - what are we saying --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: If I - if I separated children from their parents, and I went to dinner at a Mexican restaurant, I would realize--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well how about - how about if I endorse--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --that there's a possibility--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --third-term abortions? I mean there are lots of things I disagree with, and find repugnant that you support. But I'm not going to--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Hey, you're not a public--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --yell at you.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --official, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No. So, is it OK to scream at Nancy Pelosi until she leaves a restaurant? And the answer is "No, it's not OK." It's never OK.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I - I think what happened with Nancy Pelosi was fine, the other day. She was walking out of a fundraiser and a group was protesting--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: If she was going with her daughters --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --you don't see any - you don't see any of us yelling about it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --if I walked up and said, "Nancy Pelosi, I'm going to yell at you until you leave The Palm because you have a - you support a policy I disagree with." I think a normal person would say, you know what--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: You're crying how pathetical --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --if you don't like make --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --that's not what happened at any of those instances.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I've noticed because Conservatives don't do it because they're not monsters.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: In the last 10 days, Donald Trump used the name George Soros for the first time in his presidency, and the guy had a pipe bomb in his mailbox last night. And we're talking about whether or not--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Wait --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --whether or not Sarah Sanders gets her corn at Hen --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --who and all put a pipe bomb in George Soros'--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --why do you think--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --mailbox?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --why do you think they did? You think it's just --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Because Trump criticized George Soros, one of the richest people--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --coincidence? Because Donald Trump--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --in the world?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --Donald Trump runs around--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, because George Soros maybe you count --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Don't laugh.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --I'm laughing because--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Laughing why?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --to draw a connection between Trump, Soros, I've criticized Soros a thousand times. I hope he'll live long enough I can continue to criticize him.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: But you're not Donald Trump. I'm not Donald Trump. He has - he has- -

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Our elected leaders are not allowed to criticize George Soros?

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --come on. In 642 days, if there's an angry mob--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No, no, I'm serious, look--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --if - if - if we'd gone from coconut juice and soy to angry mob, and everyone is so worried about violence, why has Donald Trump not said everyone needs to dial it down? The rhetoric in our society--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I think - I think--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --he has never said that, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --he said it. Mobs shouldn't assault people.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: He's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --everybody's like oh mob, you're racist--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --racist.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: He calls Democrats--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --an angry mob.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well they are an angry mob--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: Jobs not angry mobs.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --and I hate that stuff.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: It's catchy but he needs--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's all but true.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --fear and hatred to succeed.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: He has no interest in taming it down.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: He's never screamed at people in restaurants.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: He's --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It was great to see you --

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --it's his responsibility.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I'm going to let you dine--

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: I just came from BLT--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --without being harassed.

utterances.speaker: REINES
utterances.utterance: --at Trump Hotel.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: No one yelled at you, exactly. Democratic Party Keith Ellison has been accused of abusing an ex- girlfriend. She's gone public, and she'll tell us the story next, and what happened to her after she did.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Two weeks from now, DNC Deputy Chairman Keith Ellison may become the Attorney General of the State of Minnesota. This despite allegations of abuse that have been leveled at him by his ex-girlfriend, Karen - Karen Monahan. Karen Monahan is a Liberal. She's a Democrat. But she's also complained about the poor treatment she's received from fellow Democrats since she was bold enough to go public with her allegations. Has anything changed in the weeks since she said that? Well Karen Monahan and her attorney, Andrew Parker, join us tonight. Thank you both for coming on.

utterances.speaker: ANDREW PARKER, KAREN MONAHAN'S LAWYER
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: KAREN MONAHAN, KEITH ELLISON ACCUSER
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So Karen, you had said publicly that since coming forward with your claims against Keith Ellison that you were, in effect, blacklisted by fellow Democrats. Can you describe what you meant when you said that?

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: Well, I think if you look on social media, if you see some of the letters that have been written that basically say they don't believe me, the folks who have signed on you it's pretty apparent. There's been a lot of bullying. There's been a lot of harassment, isolation by many folks that I stood side by side with supporting them in their campaigns, walking with them in various protest, worked together on different issues around social justice.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Were you so - I mean that's not the reception that people who say they're survivors of abuse expect they're going to get from the Left, from Democrats. Were you surprised by it?

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: No. I watched the MeToo movement. It was, you know, both - I've watched both sides basically take women's pain and use it as a tool for politics. And once it came to one side or the other, you would see these same people start pushing away from it and saying stuff like, "Well let's talk about the real issues." And this is a real issue.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Andrew Parker, do you think that the Democratic organization in Minnesota investigated this in a legitimate way, these claims?

utterances.speaker: PARKER
utterances.utterance: No, it wasn't legitimate at all. Any objective review of it would reach the same conclusion. The Democratic National Committee kicked it to the DFL party in the State of Minnesota who hired their lawyer to investigate their candidate for Attorney General. And not just their Candidate, Tucker, for Attorney General but cause celeb for the Democratic Party, a leader of the progressive movement, not just in Minnesota, but nationally, the Vice Chair of the Democratic National Committee is who they were investigating and they hired their own lawyer, not an outside independent lawyer, their own lawyer--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PARKER
utterances.utterance: --and - and a law firm that raised over half a million dollars for Democratic candidates and over $50,000 for Keith Ellison himself.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's not legitimate. Karen you have said or allegedly there is a video that shows you being dragged off the bed by Keith Ellison, him swearing at you. Does that video exist?

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Will the public have a chance to see it?

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: Well the public will not have a chance to see it. That's my pain. And for something like that for everybody to look at and ogle over, something that was--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: --very traumatizing for me, absolutely not. I would not allow the public to see it. If and when I decide to show it to somebody, it will be in my time. I mean this is a process and just to find the courage to come out and break my silence, as I said, knowing the backlash that I would get, and knowing that this is a journey that I would walk pretty much on my own it took tremendous amount of courage. And I had to face the same fears that so many others who have been victimized face when they decide to either share their story or not tell - share their story.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So--

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: It's also the same - it's also the same kind of fear that many people who actually know about this situation, have known about it long before I ever shared went - went public with it, why they sit silent or they're afraid to show public support. Many have been bullied and intimidated if they did come out and show any kind of public support, and I grappled with that same fear, the fear of isolation, the fear of being re-victimized--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well but that's - that's what you're not supposed to feel--

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: --being smeared.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --according to the people who are making you feel that way. Thank you both for joining us tonight. I appreciate your taking the time to talk to us and tell us what happened. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: MONAHAN
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: PARKER
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well the administration has infuriated the Left once again, this time, by defending science. But wait, we thought the Left was for science. But it turns out they're not. And if you are, you're a bad person. That's a topic that's addressed at some length in a new book called Ship of Fools. You can purchase it at TuckerCarlson.com.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.utterance: ORDER TUCKER'S BOOK AT TuckerCarlson.com.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Federal law prohibits gender discrimination. Various federal programs offer special loans to female business owners. Congress sets rules for how women need to be treated in the workforce and universities. There are literally dozens of government agencies that exist in part due to the long-standing presumption that men and women are biologically distinct. They're different. Now, the Trump Administration in the spirit of all of that wants to define gender on a clear scientific basis, but is running into headwinds politically in trying to do that. Tammy Bruce joins us tonight to respond.

utterances.speaker: TAMMY K. BRUCE, ON-AIR CONTRIBUTOR, FOX NEWS, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: Hey, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So Tammy, let me just ask you, what happens to women if the definition of sex, of gender becomes up to the discretion of the individual?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well your opening comments, I think, made that pretty clear. We have a scientific framework that recognizes women and men. As a woman who's worked most of my adult life for the welfare of women, that's important. You know, we are important. We lead different kinds of lives. Our - our life experiences are different. We're subject to certain kinds of, different kinds of violence, sexual violence etcetera. So, I mean it's important but the - the important thing also is when it comes to the government and law is that something is actually administratable that something is clear, that something is defined. And, of course, science, as the Left always tells us, is important, and as - and as an - a - a distinctive framework of how we make decisions. The problem here is, is that Barack Obama created a framework where for Title IX, people could - would be judged and placed in a framework based on simply what they claimed. Now, I think the transgendered issue is a serious one, people going through--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: --serious life changes. Chelsea Manning just posted Twitter photos with her having the surgery. We know, of course, Caitlyn Jenner has. Hundreds of Americans have gone through this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: And it's a serious issue. And I think that what we're looking at here for the government, especially as a gay woman, if you're looking for the government to, and the reaction to this change has been remarkable to confirm your value or your existence as a person, we're all in trouble because the government is not the place to get that. Right now, any kind of rule, I think, for the government's got to be something that helps us administrate a framework like Title IX and recognize the differences between men and women while transgendered individuals, of course, this doesn't erase them. It means that their relationship with themselves and with the medical community and how they identify--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: --remain - is personal and that they can work through the system within that framework.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean it's not an attack on anyone to--

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --to start to worry that maybe women are - are about to be hurt in this. That - that's my opinion because --

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Well, yes--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --we should at least talk it through, I think--

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Well - well yes--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --rationally. And I'm glad that you helped us do that.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Tammy, thank you.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well getting into Harvard is tough for anybody, but it's a lot harder for some, and it depends on your skin color to a large extent, it turns out. We know that because of documents related to a discrimination lawsuit brought by Asian applicants to Harvard. And those documents show the University has spent decades rigging its admissions policies at the behest of University leaders, who want a significantly less Asian student body. It's hard to believe but that is happening even today. Jason Hill is a Philosophy Professor at DePaul University and author of the book We Have Overcome. He opposes the admissions practices of Harvard. Jason, thanks a lot for joining us. So, a lot of us grew up hearing about the discriminatory practices of the Harvard Admissions Department believing that they were no longer in existence, only to discover that they are, and that Harvard is defending them, even having been caught using them.

utterances.speaker: JASON HILL, PHILOSOPHY PROFESSOR, DEPAUL UNIVERSITY
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: What is this?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.utterance: Well I think this is - there's no other word to describe it than just nefarious. I mean any institution that uses race explicitly as a way and ex - explicitly uses race with such zeal as a way of excluding persons from their institutions is just plain evil. And what makes it even more nefarious is that we're talking about a group that has achieved the highest academic record, the highest SAT scores, but has the lowest admission rate among any racial group. This makes it even more nefarious and - and - and - and I just - I think the word that comes to my mind is evil here. This is plain --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So but--

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.utterance: --and - and --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --if you're telling kids, and we do tell kids all through young adulthood through their teen years and high school, we say, "Get the highest grades you can and the highest test scores," those are the criteria that are going to be used to judge you. And it turns out that's a lie. It makes all of us kind of cynical, doesn't it? This - this fake meritocracy?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.utterance: It's - it's profoundly anti-American. And it's - it's - it goes in the face of - of - of - of what is - as - is - is - is the American dream, which is meritocracy, which is going by fairness, which is going by working hard, not judging people by race, by ethnicity, by, you know, morally neutral factors, but judging people based on merit, on talent, on sheer grit, and ten - tenacity and resilience. And what Harvard is saying is that there are other criteria that we're going to judge you by, a superfluous and extraneous criteria, and anything that you exhibit such as talent and merit, we're actually going to discount those and use them against you. And when we have a model group that aspire to the best virtues that America can offer, such as grit, tenacity, and hard work--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.utterance: --and display those to the American people, we say we're going to discount those, and we're going to actually use them against you. And I think that's just very, very unfair.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: They believed in our values and we punish them for it. It's really sad. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.utterance: We punish them for it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You put that so nicely. Professor, thanks a lot.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well he hosts the most popular television show in the A.M. He has written a bunch of best-selling books. He can probably bake 30-minute brownies in five minutes. Brian Kilmeade joins us after the break, we are honored to say. Stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Time now for the Friend Zone. We bring on one of our favorite people here at Fox. Tonight, we're honored to be joined by one of the co- hosts of Fox & Friends, the great Brian Kilmeade. His new book, Andrew Jackson and The Miracle of New Orleans, a best-seller sold so well, it's now out in paperback, and we are proud to be the forum in which he announces that. So Brian, all this drama going on, you spent a lot of time thinking about Andrew Jackson and studying his presidency, what are the lessons from Jackson that we could apply to this moment? How would he handle the drama we're living through? BRIAN KILMEADE, FOX & FRIENDS CO-HOST, FOX NEWS: Straight ahead, very similar to Trump. And that's one of the most amazing thing, Tucker. I could say lucked out but also when you write a history book, you worry about being relevant. People like you and I like politics, like history, lot of our audience does. But I had no idea that President Trump was even going to run for president, let alone win and be so compared, and accurately, to Andrew Jackson, and put his portrait up in the Oval Office. I had no idea his - his tomb would be defiled for the first time since his death, prior to the Civil War because all of a sudden, Andrew Jackson's being re-evaluated. Suddenly, the previous president wanted him off the 20. We can never justify slavery but he had slaves. We can never justify some of the battles he had with American Indians at the time, but others was in order to win a war called the War of 1812. So, having done that, he was still an unbelievable success story that in the afterward I have Lincoln, Teddy Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Ronald Reagan, all looked up to him and said, "I can learn from this guy." I'm amazed today we're having trouble finding relevance, good things about Andrew Jackson, a 13-year-old orphan who ended up a two-term president. That's the American story.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: One of the toughest people ever to hold the Office, I - I think by popular claim.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He shot people in duels. He had a bullet in him his entire life. He suffered from dysentery, 6' 1'', a 140 pounds. He was brought up in the backwoods. There were no social programs to prop him up. He found a way. He didn't blame. He took action. Became a self-taught lawyer, Judge, Congressman, Senator, a Militia General. Won some of the most consequential battles, including the Battle of New Orleans, that any American General has ever won. And get this, he didn't go to West Point. He didn't learn his leadership from his - from his father. He learned it from being raised by his town, his County, his country, and he bled red, white, and blue. And he lived to pay back that country for what they did for him and that give him a shot at life. In no other country could he have done anything. He was one of the original American success stories even if you didn't like some of his policies.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Amazing. This is why the book has sold the number of copies it has.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's a great story and a great account of an amazing life. Brian, thank you very much. The great Brian Kilmeade.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: All right, go get them, Tucker. Thanks.
